title: Man fined for refusing to remove balaclava at Epping protest
summary:
Epping protester fined for not removing balaclava2 days ago Share Save Aimee Dexter Share SaveReuters Joshua Meadows, 18, refused to remove a face covering during a protest outside The Bell Hotel in EppingA protester who cited burkas when refusing to remove his face covering outside a hotel housing asylum seekers in Epping has been fined £276.
Joshua Meadows, 18, from the Essex town, would not remove a "full face" balaclava when asked to do so by police during a protest at The Bell Hotel on 24 July, Chelmsford Magistrates' Court heard.
Prosecutor Celestia John-Baptiste said: "He said he didn't know why he, as a white British person, could not wear a face covering when people could wear burkas."
Meadows pleaded guilty to failing to remove an item when asked by a constable, and possession of cannabis.
"They were asked to remove the coverings, and all did so except for the defendant," she said.

title: The UK announces mandatory digital ID plans
summary:
The United Kingdom is introducing a national digital ID scheme in an effort to crack down on illegal migrant workers.
“Digital ID is an enormous opportunity for the UK.
Plans to introduce digital ID were announced in January, with the GOV.UK wallet app initially pitched to give UK citizens the option to digitize their driver’s licenses and make government-issued documents easier to access.
The GOV.UK wallet app is still in development, and described as “entirely optional” on the government website.
The UK currently has no citizen ID card and does not legally require people to carry photo ID, such as passports or driver’s licenses.

title: Trump UN speech: Seven years ago his audience laughed, this year they were silent
summary:
Over almost an hour, he took aim at his opponents and their ideas, picking them off one by one as he toured the world.
The president even attacked the UN for a broken escalator and teleprompter that disrupted his visit and speech.
Under Trump, the US has withdrawn much of its UN funding, leaving the body forced to cut its humanitarian work around the world.
Trump saved perhaps his biggest criticism for his European allies, attacking the continent for investing in renewable energy, and opening its borders to migration.

title: Trump's Manufacturing, Immigration, Prices Priorities Are in Conflict
summary:
The president wants to boost US manufacturing, cut down on immigration, and keep prices down all at once.
If there has been one throughline to the president's economic agenda, it's his desire to rebuild American manufacturing and get companies to make things here.
The most glaring deterrent for foreign companies looking to move some operations to America's shores is Trump's immigration crackdown.
But increased prices on foreign goods give domestic companies cover to raise their prices.
In an ideal world, there would be a boom in job growth, in manufacturing and otherwise, that disproportionately benefited American workers.

title: Trump officials rally global leaders for restrictions on asylum seekers
summary:
On Thursday, Deputy Secretary of State Christopher Landau led a panel called “Global Refugee Asylum System: What Went Wrong and How to Fix It”, where he called upon other countries to crack down on asylum seekers.
“If you have hundreds of thousands of fake asylum seekers, then what happens to the real asylum system?” Landau said.
Among the changes the Trump administration has sought is a reimagining of the asylum system, which started to take shape following World War II.
“The asylum system has become a huge loophole in our migration laws,” Landau said.
In his speech to the UN General Assembly this week, Trump argued that accepting immigrants was “destroying” other countries.
